properties.desc: "a suburb of Warsaw" (14)
"At first, in a new home on Zielna Street, we knew real comfort." (15)

"The Nazis are beginning to intensify their acts of terrorism against the native population, especially the Jews. Last week they set fire to the great synagogue, the pride of the Lodz community. They forbade the Jews to remove the sacred books, and the 'shames' or beadle who wanted to save the holy relics was locked up inside the temple and died in the flames." (19)
"This is only the third day of our internment in the Pawiak prison . . ."(162)

"I felt choked by tears when we drove down Leszno Street. How much Jewish blood has been shed here. . . . We were silent, and our Gentile companions sympathized with us." (216, leaving Pawiak prison))

"We have been in Biarritz for several hours. The train halted two miles from the main station. Among the passengers there is a growing fear. According to some rumors, a number of the internees will be sent back to Vittel, because there are allegedly too many of us to exchange." (250)
"On March 15 our ship approached New York. . . . I saw the skyscrapers of New York, but my thoughts were in Warsaw and I was talking with Rutka."

"Today we received a communication from the housing office concerning the janitorial job my father is supposed to take over at 10 Chlodna Street. He must go there at once, but we shall be allowed to move in only after the street is walled up." (121)

"At 16 Sienna Street, in the house where our courses in graphic arts took place, a new café, directed by Tatiana Epstein, has been opened. . . . Famous artists give performances there, among them the virtuoso Wladislaw Spielman. In a few days this café is going to run a contest for young talent. . . . I have entered my name among the competitors." (55)
[Uncle Abie] managed to enter a passage that led to the uneven side of Chlodna Street; at Number 17 is a Jewish Police station.
"The janitor at 8 Chlodna Street is Engineer Plonskier, formerly our neighbor on Sienna Street. Many doctors live on our street, and there is a doctor's or dentist's sign on almost every door." (128)

"[After a description of children smugglers] The next morning the little foragers try once more to cross the ghetto boundary at the corner of Sienna and Zelazna Streets; perhaps the same kindly guard will be there who let them pass once before." (73)

properties.addrLocal: Pałac Brühla, plac marsz. Józefa Piłsudskiego
properties.desc: "Two of my friends have acquired papers proving that they are nationals of a South American republic. Thanks to these they can circulate freely in the city. They went boldly to the Gestapo headquarters at Bruehl Palace to have these papers sealed with a swastika; and the German experts did not realize that they were forged. They can even go to the country to buy food. With such documents they have at least a 90 per cent chance of survival—the other Jews have only a 10 per cent chance at most." (30)

"Today a new group of uniformed Jewish officials appeared in the ghetto. They belong to the special Commission for the Fight Against Speculators, whose task it is to regulate the prices of various articles. . . . [T]hey are suspected of being tools of the Gestapo. Their organization has been nicknamed "The Thirteen," because its office is at 13 Leszno Street." (43) [more]

"The number of professional schools and courses in the ghetto is increasing. The ORT organization has opened a special course for girls under the direction of Roma Brandes . . . The ORT has obtained two halls for these courses: at 13 Leszno Street and 13 Nalewki Street." (54)

"The relief office of the American colony in Warsaw is situated at 14 Mokotowska Street. Once a month all American citizens receive a large package of foodstuffs for the sum of eleven zlotys—but its real value is three hundred, for it often contains articles that are unobtainable elsewhere at any price whatsoever.¶The question of obtaining food is becoming ever more pressing." (40)

"The Jewish police is an accomplished fact. . . . Central Police Headquarters, the so-called KSP, are at 15 Ogrodowa Street; the five regional offices are on Twarda Street, Ogrodowa Street, Leszno Street, at Gesia near Nalwecki, and near the Jewish cemetary." (42)

"I have recognized other acquaintances among the workers employed across the street. Edzia Piaskowska's brother oversees a large group of workers at the children's home. Zelig is an overseer in the building adjoining ours, at Number 24 [sic] Dzielna Street." (180)

"Yesterday we were in a state of utter despair. The card with our furniture was ready, and we planned to occupy temporary quarters in the room of my schoolmate, Zosia Zakheim, at 24 Panska Street. Suddenly, Ola Szmuszkiewicz, my friend, came running to tell us that she had found two rooms for us in a large comfortable apartment on Leszno Street, where there is even a piano." (105)

"A search took place a few days ago in Sienna Street, at the corner of Sosnowa. The Nazis allegedly had come to requisition the furniture of a Jewish tenant, and while doing this discovered a radio station." (67) [more]

"The metallurgical and related courses will be given in the community building at 26 Grzybowska Street; the courses in industrial drawing will be given at 16 Sienna Street, not far from my home. . . . Unfortunately "pull" playes a large part in the selection of students. At first I rebelled agains this, but when I realized that my chances of being admitted were slight, I finally decided to resort to the same means." (50)

"[After a lament for engineer Czerniakow]¶President Czerniakow lives at 26 Elektoralna Street. I often come to this house because a friend of mine lives there, but I have never met the president on the stairs or in the street. He seldom goes out, for he is entirely absorbed by his heavy tasks. . . . ¶I have had occasion to see President Czerniakow during his visits to our school." (57)

"Close to our window we sometimes see a Jewish policeman walking out of Numbers 27–31 Dzielna Street, which is Dr. Janusz Korczak's children's home. I can see many little beds through the windows of this house. During moments of quiet I hear the sweet voices of the children who live there, quite unaware of what is happening around them." (168) [more, including departure of children to massacre]

[reduction of Ghetto] "The area of the ghetto has been considerably reduced. Its boundary now runs along Smocza, Gesia, Franciszkanska, Bonifraterska, Muranowska, Pokorna, Stawki, Dzika and Szczesliwa Street, and Parysowski [sic] Square. All the community institutions and remaining workshops were ordered to transfer to the new area. This order of the German authorities bears the date of September 27." (189)

"Late at night we arrived in Neuburg, where we were again given a meal, this time better and more abundant than the previous one. . . . Apparently, the Nazis want us, Americans, to tell everyone that Germany is not lacking in anything." (218)
"A few minutes ago I awoke from my sleep. I cannot believe my eyes, and I still do not know whether I am dreaming or waking. Our train is moving in the direction of Poznan, not of Oswiecim." 216
"We are now approaching Zbaszyn on the former Polish-German frontier." (217)

properties.notes: Roughly the path travelled by Berg family when the German invasion of Poland started.
Berg uses strange writing here, saying that the Jewish police occupy 'an entire block', when these two streets don't form a block.
properties.desc: "The Jewish police now occupies an entire block on Ostrowska and Wolynska Streets. All the Jewish policemen and their families were ordered to leave their former apartments in the various quarters of the ghetto and to occupy the emptied and looted apartments of the deported." (184–85) [more]
"Our first performance took place early this month at 5 Przejazd, in the Joint Distribution Committee office. Our success surpassed all expectations, and the receipts were considerable." (37)

"My father stayed in the cellar the entire day and prayed to God while my mother looked for a new apartment. She has not found anything so far, but brought home a new piece of sad news: it seems that the Nazis are going to liquidate the so-called Little Ghetto and add only Chlodna Street and the further end of Zelazna to the Big Ghetto." (103)

"My father stayed in the cellar the entire day and prayed to God while my mother looked for a new apartment. She has not found anything so far, but brought home a new piece of sad news: it seems that the Nazis are going to liquidate the so-called Little Ghetto and add only Chlodna Street and the further end of Zelazna to the Big Ghetto." (103)
properties.notes: Not immediately obvious what her language means specifically, but Chlodna is short and Zelazna is short enough that this stretch must be what she's talking about. Engelking-Boni maps will be helpful here.

properties.desc: "¶Komitetowa Street, near Grzybowska, is a living graveyard of children devoured by scurvy. The inhabitants of this street live in long cellar-caves into which no ray of the sun ever reaches." (88)

"The Nazis strictly follow the Jewish calendar. Yesterday before sunset, at the time of the Kol Nidre prayers which open the Day of Atonement services, big white placards were posted with the sad announcement that before October 5 the inhabitants of the right [odd-numbered] side of Sienna Street, of sections of Gesia and Muranowska Streets and of a number of houses near the ghetto boundaries must leave their apartments." (103)
properties.notes: Temporarily blue so as to distinguish it from the last ghetto reduction.

properties.desc: "On Sunday, September 6, the Jewish police force received an order to prepare for another campaign. This followed an announcement published by the community in the name of the Resettlement Commission, according to which all the remaining inhabitants of the "Big Ghetto" (within the limits of Smocza, Gesia, Zamenhof, and Szczesliwa Streets, and Parisowski Square) were to report on September 5 for registration." (184)
"I feel as though I have been in Vittel for a long time. ¶This is a large camp. In the park there are three hotels: the Grand Hotel, the Vittel Palace, and the Ceres." (219)

properties.notes: Location is American embassy in Warsaw, not consulate in Lodz, and it's not for sure that this is the location of the embassy. The Warsaw phone directory of 1939 says "Ujazdowska 29", so is that a misprint for Ujazdowskie?
properties.desc: "Last week we received a letter from the American consulate, summoning my mother to Warsaw. The mailman who brought us this letter could not refrain from expressing his envy over the fact that we have American connections." (24)
Train transit from Poznan to Zbaszyn
Berg journeys to America

"Every day, morning and afternoon, when I go to school, I am not sure whether I will return alive. I have to go past two of the most dangerous German sentry posts: at the corner of Zelazna and Chlodna Streets near the bridge, and at the corner of Krochmalna and Grzybowska Streets." (135)

"Every day, morning and afternoon, when I go to school, I am not sure whether I will return alive. I have to go past two of the most dangerous German sentry posts: at the corner of Zelazna and Chlodna Streets near the bridge, and at the corner of Krochmalna and Grzybowska Streets." (135)
